person_218.name: Physicus
person_218.description: A fictional character in Davy's Salmonia: Or, Days of Fly-fishing (1828).

person_217.name: Halieus
person_217.description: A fictional character in Davy's Salmonia: Or, Days of Fly-fishing (1828).

person_1074.name: Amédée-BarthélémyBerthollet
person_1074.description: The son of chemist Claude Louis Berthollet, he died of carbon monoxide poisoning via charcoal-burning suicide in which he had recorded his physiological and psychological experiences as a final scientific contribution before losing consciousness and succumbing to the fumes.

person_243.name: WilliamCullen
person_243.description: Scottish physician and chemist. Professor of Medicine at Glasgow University and then Edinburgh. FRSL.

person_142.name: CharlesBlagden
person_142.description: Physician who kept a revealing diary for most of his life. A friend of Joseph Banks serving as a Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1784-1797; Knighted 1792. FRSL

person_012.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
person_012.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

person_897.name: MarkCatesby
person_897.description: English naturalist who studied the flora and fauna of the New World.

person_098.name: JosephineDetela
person_098.description: The daughter of the landlord of the Laybach (Ljubljana) inn at which Davy stayed in 1827 and 1828. Davy nicknamed her 'Pepina'. In Consolations in Travel (1830) he portrayed her in idealised terms as his nurturing nurse.

person_018.name: DavidHartley
person_018.description: Associationist, whose work argued that the vibrations of nerves created sensation. FRSL.

person_1075.name: JosephAddison
person_1075.description: an English essayist, poet, playwright, and politician.

person_597.name: FrancescoFerrara
person_597.description: Italian geologist, active mainly in Sicily, and known especially for his vulcanology studies.

person_213.name: JohnHunter
person_213.description: Leading Scottish surgeon and anatomist who worked in London, holding several major positions. Brother of William Hunter. FRSL.

person_269.name: LuigiGalvani
person_269.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_199.name: AlessandroVolta
person_199.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

person_525.name: JohnWalsh
person_525.description: Nabob and later an MP he experimented on the electrical properties of torpedo fish. FRSL.

person_888.name: Hans ChristianØrsted
person_888.description: Danish physicist and chemist who won the Copley Medal in 1820 for his electro-chemical experiments and discoveries; he had become a professor at the University of Copenhagen in 1806.

person_1076.name: FrancescoRedi
person_1076.description: Italian physician and naturalist. He is referred to as the "founder of experimental biology"

person_789.name: Giovanni AlfonsoBorelli
person_789.description: Italian physicist, physiologist and mathematician who is often described as the father of biomechanics.

person_266.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
person_266.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

person_241.name: Johann FriedrichBlumenbach
person_241.description: Professor of Medicine at Göttingen University. Race theorist who applied comparative anatomy to classification of human races. ForMemRSL.

person_240.name: ErasmusDarwin
person_240.description: Physician and natural philosopher who was member of the Lunar Society and friend of Priestley and Watt; also a correspondent with Beddoes. FRSL.

person_975.name: Johann GasparSpurzheim
person_975.description: a German physician who became one of the chief proponents of phrenology.

place_238.name: Southern Provinces
place_238.description: The southern provinces of Austria are Tyrol, Carinthia, and Styria.

place_216.name: Ljubljana
place_216.description: Also known as Laybach or Laibach. Ljubljana is the capital city of Slovenia.

place_269.name: Kammersee
place_269.description: The Kammersee, or Attersee, is a lake in Upper Austria.

place_1341.name: Golling an der Salzach
place_1341.description: Golling an der Salzach is a market town in the Hallein district of Salzburg, Austria.

place_774.name: Bad Ischl
place_774.description: Bad Ischl is a spa town in Austria. It lies in the southern part of Upper Austria, at the River Traun in the centre of the Salzkammergut region.

place_182.name: Traun
place_182.description: Traunfall in Desselbrunn, Upper Austria. Memoirs contains a poem Davy wrote about them, also in notebook 14E.

place_214.name: Sava River
place_214.description: The Sava River, 990km in length, rises in Slovenia (Carnolia) and is the largest tributary of the Danube by volume of water.

place_260.name: Drava River
place_260.description: The Drava is a river in central southern Europe and is the fifth longest tributary of the Danube.

place_268.name: Ager River
place_268.description: The Ager River in Austria is a tributary of the Traun.

place_229.name: Bad Aussee
place_229.description: In Styria (Bad Aussee). Bad Aussee is a town in the Austrian state of Styria located at the confluence of the three sources of the Traun River.

place_264.name: Grundlsee
place_264.description: Grundlsee is a municipality in Styria, Austria.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_257.name: Gmunden
place_257.description: Gmunden is a town in Upper Austria, frequented as a health and summer resort.

place_400.name: Vöcklabruck
place_400.description: Vöcklabruck is a town in the western part of Upper Austria.

place_270.name: Voecla
place_270.description: The Vockla River runs through Upper Austria and is a tributary of the Ager River.

place_197.name: Salzburg
place_197.description: Salzburg is an Austrian city on the border of Germany, with views of the Eastern Alps.

place_1338.name: Frankenmarkt
place_1338.description: Town on the Vöckla river, roughly one third of the way between Vöcklabruck and Salzburg.

place_1339.name: Vöcklamarkt
place_1339.description: Town on the Vöckla river, between Vöcklabruck and Frankenmarkt

place_895.name: Kammer
place_895.description: Today the Schloss Kammer - Kammer Castle is situated on a peninsula, originally on an island in the northern Attersee

place_1340.name: Seekirchen am Wallersee
place_1340.description: a town in the district of Salzburg-Umgebung in the state of Salzburg in Austria.

place_217.name: River Danube
place_217.description: The Danube is the second longest river in Europe. It flows through central and south eastern Europe into the Black Sea.

place_1342.name: Werfen
place_1342.description: Werfen is a market town in the district of St. Johann im Pongau, in the Austrian state of Salzburg.

place_781.name: Untertauern
place_781.description: Untertauern is a municipality in the district of St Johann im Pongau in the Austrian state of Salzburg.

place_680.name: Radstadt
place_680.description: Radstadt is a town in the Austrian state of Salzburg.

place_779.name: Tamsweg
place_779.description: Tamsweg is a market town in the Austrian state of Salzburg near the border with Styria.

place_850.name: Murau
place_850.description: A town in the western part of the Austrian federal state of Styria.

place_602.name: Mur River
place_602.description: The Mur or Mura is a river in Central Europe rising in the Hohe Tauern national park of the Central Eastern Alps in Austria.

place_1343.name: Friesach
place_1343.description: Friesach is a historic town in the Sankt Veit an der Glan district of Carinthia, Austria.

place_674.name: Klagenfurt
place_674.description: Klagenfurt is the capital city of the Austrian state of Carinthia.

place_672.name: Sankt Veit im Innkreis
place_672.description: Sankt Veit im Innkreis is a town in Upper Austria.

place_245.name: Ravenna
place_245.description: Ravenna is a city in the north-east of Italy, near the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

place_256.name: Wurzen Pass
place_256.description: Wurzen Pass is a mountain pass in a col of the Karawanks Mountain range between the Austrian state of Carinthia and the the Slovenian Kranjska Gora. It is named after the town of Podkoren (Wurzen).

place_192.name: Illyrian Alps
place_192.description: Illyria was the name of a mountainous region in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe.

place_355.name: Rhone River
place_355.description: A major river in France and Switzerland.

place_266.name: Rhine
place_266.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

place_848.name: Velino
place_848.description: A river in central Italy, a tributary of the Nera.

place_565.name: Terni
place_565.description: Terni is a city in the southern portion of the region of Umbria in central Italy.

place_955.name: Rieti
place_955.description: A town and comune in Lazio, central Italy,

place_926.name: Sabina
place_926.description: Also called the Sabine Hills, a region in central Italy.

place_530.name: Apennines
place_530.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

place_342.name: Ratmansdorff
place_342.description: Also known as Radovljica. Radovljica is a town in the Upper Carnolia region of Slovenia, located on the banks of the Sava River.

place_1344.name: Bled
place_1344.description: a Slovenian resort town in the foothills of the Julian Alps alongside Lake Bled

place_181.name: Carniola
place_181.description: The Alpine region whose capital was Laybach (now Ljubljana). In 1827, Carniola was a Duchy within the Austrian Kingdom of Illyria.

place_1345.name: Novo Mesto
place_1345.description: Formerly Neustadtl, Novo Mesto is the seventh-largest city of Slovenia. It is the economic and cultural centre of the traditional region of Lower Carniola and the seat of the City Municipality of Novo Mesto. It lies on a bend of the Krka River, close to the border with Croatia

place_595.name: Gradaščica River
place_595.description: The Gradaščica is a river in Slovenia. It begins in Polhov Gradec at the confluence of Little Creek and Big Božna Creek.

place_1064.name: Planina
place_1064.description: A village in the Inner Carniola region of Slovenia.

place_519.name: Trieste
place_519.description: Trieste is the capital city of the Friuli Venezia Giulia region in north-east Italy. A port city, it occupies a thin strip of land between the Adriatic coast and Slovenia’s border on the limestone-dominated Karst Plateau.

place_1248.name: Postojna
place_1248.description: a town in the traditional region of Inner Carniola, in southwestern Slovenia

place_1346.name: Cerknica
place_1346.description: Known in German as Zirknitz, Cerknica is a town in the Karst region of southwestern Slovenia.

place_553.name: Ljubljanica River
place_553.description: The Ljubljanica is a river in the southern part of the Ljubljana Basin in Slovenia. Davy also refers to the "fall of the Lubiana"  as Kaltenbrun.

place_989.name: Calais
place_989.description: A port city in North-West France

place_586.name: Gorizia
place_586.description: Gorizia is a town and comune in north-eastern Italy, in the autonomous region of Friuli Venezia Giulia.

place_587.name: Pordenone
place_587.description: Pordenone is a comune of the north-east Italian region of Friuli Venezia Giulia.

place_1075.name: Padua
place_1075.description: A province and a city in italy, west of Venice.

place_1079.name: Rovigo
place_1079.description: A city and comune in the Veneto region of Northeast Italy.

place_942.name: Bologna
place_942.description: A city in and the capital of the Emilia-Romagna region in Northern Italy, of which it is also its largest.

place_728.name: Rimini
place_728.description: A city in north-eastern Italy located on the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

place_547.name: Fano
place_547.description: Fano is a town and comune of the province of Pesaro and Urbino in the Marche region of Italy.

place_544.name: Fossombrone
place_544.description: Fossombrone is a town and comune in the province of Pesaro e Urbino, Marche, central Italy.

place_542.name: Cagli
place_542.description: Cagli is a town and comune in the province of Pesaro e Urbino, Marche, central Italy.

place_549.name: Nocera Umbra
place_549.description: Nocera Umbra is a town and comune in the province of Perugia, Italy.

place_564.name: Foligno
place_564.description: Foligno is an ancient town of Italy in the province of Perugia in east central Umbria, on the Topino river.

place_1347.name: Baccano
place_1347.description: A town in Italy in the Campagnano di Roma

place_156.name: Naples
place_156.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

place_1212.name: Arabian Peninsula
place_1212.description: a peninsula in West Asia, situated northeast of Africa on the Arabian Plate. It includes the territories of includes Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Yemen, as well as southern Iraq and Jordan. In the classical era, the Sinai Peninsula was also considered a part of Arabia.

place_199.name: The Colosseum
place_199.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

otherwork_042.name: Salmonia: or Days of Fly Fishing. In a Series of Conversations.
otherwork_042.author: Humphry Davy

otherwork_037.name: Consolations in Travel, or the Last Days of Philosopher
otherwork_037.author: Humphry Davy
